reviewText:
The permadeath sounds like a good idea...until touch a zombie, die, have to watch a game over screen that takes far too long to get through, and then start over right back at the beginning. Starting over means doing the exact same things you already did in the same order you already did them.

If there were randomized elements or at least some sort of checkpoint system it would make the game enjoyable. Think of it like the movie Groundhog Day, where Bill Murray can alter the rest of the day just by making a different choice. There will be none of that in Eaten Alive, as it's straight forward mirroring what you've done and hoping you don't get within spitting distance of a zombie before you can get to that point (and a little further) all over again.

As far as death, you only have to graze a zombie and it is INSTANT death. There's no trying to push it away, no kicks to topple them over - you're just 100% done.

I like the idea of RPG Maker games that aren't the standard RPG, such as horror or mystery/adventure. So, with that being the point of interest for me, I went ahead and played this long enough to get a feel for it. I'll play it some more later, but I just hope the repetitiveness isn't going to keep me from getting at least a little fun.

So, if you don't care about doing ♥♥♥♥ over, and over, and over, and over, buy it, it's otherwise decent. But my final verdict is that some changes need to be made by the developer before it's going to be a recommendable game.

No save system.

Now, I understand how the developer is going with permadeath, and I think that makes the game a good bit more fun, but there should be a way for you to be able to save your progress if you have to stop playing. I also think that if you die the save should  be erased so you cant go back, thus keeping permadeath. I dont the dev doesnt realizes is that alot of us have things to do, whether it be work, school, social life etc. and cant keep this game running all day till we're able to play again.

I mean I think Ive barely cratched the surface of content this game has to offer, and props to the dev for making it so, but I had to stop playing because I had to go to work, and when I came home and booted the game up, I had to start over. And I REALLLLY dont wanna do the crap I have already done again.

I mean think of a survival game, like Day Z for instance. If you log out and log back in, you have everything, but if you are killed you  have to start over. Thats how this game should be.

reviewText: Eaten Alive is a RPG maker style game. It has very little in the way of settings, no save feature and permadeath. You have no real way to defend yourself in the beginning except to run and dodge the zombies. The dodge move is performed by hitting the space bar at the correct time and if you don't hit it correctly, one touch from the zombie= instadeath and start over. The dev did add a checkpoint system, but it is only good if you quit the game so that you don't have to restart from the beginning, but if you die you start from the very beginning. The menu is poorly designed, not very clear on how to navigate. The mouse controls are not good, very imprecise, the cursor looks like a middle finger and you can't interact with something if you're right next to it. It starts in windowed mode and when I put to full screen nothing worked. The dialoge would not move forward and the game froze. The story isn't very interesting and consists of poorly written dialoge and too much profanity. You can walk on walls and stand on the clocks that are hanging on the walls you are standing on. There are plenty of bugs in this game, permadeath, poor controls and no save feature that make this game one I would not recommend.

reviewText:
So, I love zombie games. A lot. This seemed pretty interesting at first glance. Not to mention super cheap. However, there are some pretty major flaws in the game itself.

-For starters, it took a LOT of player nagging for the developers to even a save function for people not wanting to play for however many hours straight.
-Additionally, there's no such thing as health or anything in this game. If you happen to accidentally bump into a zombie (whether due to actual accident or due to the shoddy pathing) you have to immediately manage to succeed in clicking at the right time or... suffer permadeath. I mean, I get that it's a hardcore permadeath game, but come on.
-To expand on the previous point, yeah. The pathing for the character is extremely shoddy at best. It'll often take the dumbest route to the clicked location, often passing right through a horde... or even a single zombie for that matter.
-Putting mechanics aside, the main character in the only available story is a piece of crap. There is no possible way to actually empathize with this character in the slightest. I get that the game is more focused on the survival component, but seriously? If you're going to put in a story, at least try to make a character that has redeeming factors. She's akin to a soulless raider or something similar.
-Another point I should add is that the fullscreen mode is rather broken. The in-game mouse cursor and out-game mouse cursor are constantly in conflict, depending on where you have your mouse on the screen.

All-in-all, I'd give this game a 5/10 at absolute best. The sprites are nice, even though they look like they are just the base sprites from the zombie pack for RPG Maker or similar, at least. The idea of the game is also alright. But that's about it for the redeeming qualities. I honestly thought for a little bit that the game was early access, but there is no early access label on the page. This feels like an alpha at best. Not a full game in the slightest.

reviewText:
Given that this was a point and click game, I thought it'd be an interesting, fun game to play.  I did see there were a lot of negative reviews, but I still wanted to give it a chance.  To be blunt, this is a terrible game.  My first complaint was the default volume of the music.  At least for me, the music got annoying pretty fast, and I ended up just turning the music off completely.  I really wish developers would set the music volume at half instead of setting it at max so it just blares in your ear.    The game starts off with two people arguing, and that's your introduction.  As you progress, you realize just how bad this story is. It even got to a point where I almost just gave up on the game and put it on my 'uninstall' list.

Lets move on with the most common thing that happens.  When you die, the game over screen seems to last forever, and then you have to start over from the very beginning.  If you're going to make us sit through a very long game over screen, at least give us check points.   As if that's not bad enough, nothing changes when you die.  It's the exact same process over and over.

One of my biggest issues is that you seem to have only 1hp.  If a zombie so much as spits on you you're dead.  I get zombie mucus is goss and all, but really?  You're going to make our death instant?  You can't even defend yourself, you just have to accept it.  That is a really, really poor mechanic.

At cetain spots I noticed you could walk onto the wall as if it wasn't there.  I'm not sure if this is intentional or an unintentional bug.  If it's intentional, why?

To my surprise, you can't alt tab.  You can't even use the Steam overlay.  I'm sorry, but how hard is it to allow us to use Steam overlay? It's a vital part of all Steam games, and it's incredibly disappointing when the option is not there.

Something that I did like was that you can use the arrow keys to move, and space to click things.  Sure, it's a point and click, you're supposed to use the mouse, but I ended up just using the arrow keys.  Always nice when you're given option to choose how you want to play/control your character.

As a final note, I do not recommend this game at all.  The only way I could see myself recommending it is if it was free.


Positives:

Trading cards.
Point and click game.
Mature game (swearing, etc)
Can use arrow keys to move around, and space bar to click on things.
Negatives:

Default music that is too loud.

Lack of a proper introduction to the game.

Far too many bugs that made the game feel like it was in early alpha.

Instant death no matter what.

reviewText:
It's pretty dire. My playtime consisted for 90% of rebooting the game because my mouse stopped working. During the little time I was actually playing all I could do was the unintuitive tutorial and the first single minute of the real game.

-The dialogues are horribly written, reminiscent of what swearing twelve-year olds would say if they were having a school play or something.

-The click-to-go-somewhere movement system is unhelpful when you are trying to run away from zombies and it is very weird how the game makes you hold shift to sprint when there is no punishment for sprinting and you have unlimited sprint. If there is no reason not to sprint I'll be sprinting all the time, so why don't you make sprinting default?

-During the tutorial I was already able to walk into a building, so it was already glitchy from the word go.

-The menu is weird and unintuitive. You can only use the mouse and when you open the options menu you can only use the keyboard for some reason. Then in that menu, the game calls the option to switch between fullscreen and windowed mode the ' resolution' option. I think they need to look again what that word means.

-The audio, while not bad in it's own right, is obnoxiously loud when you boot up the game.

-You can't alt-tab out of the game.

-Within two minutes of starting the tutorial they wheel out Jim Sterling for no reason whatsoever except perhaps to please his fans. The guy pops up out of nowhere and is about as out of place as Justin Bieber in the men's bathroom.

-The title is probably the most unimaginative one I've seen in my entire life. Not a relevant point but just something I wanted to say.

- By far the most important point: the game's mouse just stops working after a certain amount of time or doesn't even work from the word go. When that happens you can't click anything anymore and as everything is mouse-controlled you have to reboot it.

-The menu buttons are so not-button like that the button that starts the actual game looks like the title of the menu page you are currently on. They have to make that look button-like.

Avoid this like a zombie, because it eats your money alive.

So far its a pretty decent game. tweek a few things , add a save house/base and I think some more people might go for it.
